data.title: Rename scopes -> scopeDescriptor
data.body: I'm sure people will be wondering "WTF is a `scopes`?!". This gives them their own name `scopeDescriptor`. Later on we can write a doc explaining what a scope descriptor is. For now, the docs point to `Config::get` which is a nice concrete usage of scopeDescriptors.

data.title: Set up auto-updates on Windows
data.body: This PR sets up automatic updates for installations that use Squirrel for Windows by implementing `auto-updater` directly instead of using the one built into Atom Shell. Squirrel for Windows uses out-of-process updates, so wiring it up in Native Code would just mean extra suffering

data.title: Add Atom in the title bar
data.body:
This PR adds Atom in the application title bar.
Closes #3805

data.title: Add cache to atom.config
data.body: Complicated and lots of corners. Putting this here for reference. Not going to merge it.

data.title: Speedup scoped config
data.body:
Turns out `atom.config.get()` is called a ton when rendering the editor. This pull fixed some of it: https://github.com/atom/scoped-property-store/pull/4

But it was still noticeably slower when opening a tab. Here are some profiles:

Before:
![screen shot 2014-10-10 at 12 33 45 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/4619076/f477ef64-5310-11e4-87bd-5df284015c60.png)

After. No more config junk at the top of the list
![screen shot 2014-10-13 at 12 35 03 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/4619086/013be066-5311-11e4-9acf-8c359f092450.png)

It also feels much better.

data.body:
`Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'getDOMNode' of undefined /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/text-editor-component.js:1486`

Copying something off a file using `CMD-c` (with another file open), not letting go of `CMD` before pressing `CMD-w`, fires this error.

http://cl.ly/363E3c3d1o2F

I'm on Mac OS X, `10.9.5`, using Atom `0.136.0`.

data.title: Random lock ups (Editor not responding)
data.body:
I'm getting these random lock ups like once a day, and I'm not sure how to debug them or if they are atom-shell problems or atom problems or plugin problems. I don't really want to run atom in safe mode the whole day to find out whether it's a plugin problem or not. The `nohup.out` file does not provide a lot of information for me, but maybe you guys can find something useful in there:

```
[3922:1013/194458:WARNING:raw_channel_posix.cc(214)] recvmsg: Connection reset by peer
The program 'atom' received an X Window System error.
This probably reflects a bug in the program.
The error was 'BadWindow (invalid Window parameter)'.
  (Details: serial 17178 error_code 3 request_code 40 minor_code 0)
  (Note to programmers: normally, X errors are reported asynchronously;
   that is, you will receive the error a while after causing it.
   To debug your program, run it with the --sync command line
   option to change this behavior. You can then get a meaningful
   backtrace from your debugger if you break on the gdk_x_error() function.)
```

I also opened an issue at the [atom-shell repo](https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/666).

Let me know if there's anything I can do to help.

data.title: Find menu empty, packages menu gone on second window
data.body:
I'm using Atom on Arch Linux with Gnome 3.
When I start Atom I get the welcome page. After I do File>Open Folder, I get my new Atom window. When I close the old welcome window my menu in the new window starts to have problems.

When I open a folder I get this in the second window : 
![screenshot from 2014-10-12 23 11 02](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3250155/4608686/ab8be63c-5286-11e4-8dd3-605552885fce.png)
 But when I close the welcome window the second window's menu becomes :

Also, after closing the first window the Find menu has problems too :
![screenshot from 2014-10-12 23 14 41](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3250155/4608698/18ec68be-5287-11e4-8f99-019a2c96f7e9.png)

Thanks

data.title: Window title
data.body:
I'm using atom on Linux with Gnome 3.
I was wondering if it was possible to have a permanent substring in the title bar with the application name. 
![screenshot from 2014-10-12 22 57 27](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3250155/4608624/eab21df6-5284-11e4-9a8f-61283c0e0a77.png)
compared to most application :
![screenshot from 2014-10-12 23 00 21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3250155/4608630/1712d70a-5285-11e4-9b8e-ce856a37c27b.png)
In this example, sublime has "Sublime Text" in the title. My objective is to be able to use wmctrl with atom, which is the first application I'm not able to. Maybe there is other way to use wmctrl, but I didn't figured how. 
I was looking into the plugin's API and I didn't find a way to change this title. Have I overlooked something?

Thanks

data.title: :penguin: .desktop file without capital letter
data.body:
Hello,

Thank you for developing and maintaining Atom!

I'm using it on GNU/Linux Ubuntu and it seems the launcher (`.desktop` file) has a capital letter in its name. It should be renamed to `atom.desktop` because a `.desktop` file should not contain capital letters as any other `.desktop` files that we can find in `/usr/share/applications`.

Note that we also have another problem because currently, the window's class of all Atom windows is `Atom Shell` but the launcher is named `Atom`. We should also add this line in your `.desktop` file:

```
StartupWMClass=Atom Shell
```

Because without that, it's not possible for a dock/panel (like Cairo-Dock) to link a launcher (`Atom`) with its window (`Atom Shell`).

But it's certainly better to rename the window's class and this is why I just created this pull request in the `atom-shell` project! => https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/pull/698

Best Regards,

Matt

data.title: :penguin: Add split selection into lines keymap for Linux
some urls crash in iFrame
data.body:
I'm sort of cross-posting this from atom/atom-shell https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/697.

Some URLs crash in an iFrame in the atom editor but not in a test app in Atom-Shell.  Details ...

I am implementing a web browser in the Atom editor using an iFrame.  It is the package `web-browser`. When I browse most pages, like apple.com, atom.io, etc., the iFrame webpage browsing works. But when I go to some pages like gmail.com or github.com the page loads and then one second later the entire desktop window crashes (disappears) with no errors shown.

I built a quick atom-shell test app and loaded http://github.com in an iFrame with identical attributes and it worked.  I could browse github pages with no problem.

So either the Atom editor isn't using the same atom-shell version or there is something about the editor environment creating the problem.

I'm on windows 8.0.  My Atom editor is 0.136.0.  I did the atom-shell test in atom-shell 0.17.2.

Any ideas?  I'd be happy to expand my test app or do anything else I can to help find this.  I'm excited about this package and this is a show-stopper.

data.title: Keymaps do not override correctly.
data.body:
Making Ctrl+Shift+s into save-all. I noticed that if I changed int under keymaps.cson (the suggested method) the keymaps would overload, not override the default save-as. This means that when I do the command both actions take place, which is not what I intended to do. I wanted it to only execute the save-all instead of save-as ot both. 

If I change it in the local keymap.json it works fine but every time I update atom the change gets reset to default. Which is pretty annoying having to do every update. If there is a fix let me know.

Atom v0.136.0
Win 7

data.title: mkrpm grunt task
data.body:
This pull request is referring to [issue #301](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3011)

The "mkrpm" grunt task will create the rpm package in red hat Linux (Fedora, CentOS, Red Hat)

This assumes that the build task is **done**, and the rpm build tools are installed,
which can be done with the yum package manager:
- sudo yum install @development-tools
- sudo yum install fedora-packager

**NOTE**: I have only tested in the Fedora-20 machine, but it should work in
CentOS and Red Hat Linux as long as the rpm build environment is installed.

data.title: Investigate Atom + DisplayFusion
data.body:
Atom persistently causes crashes in DisplayFusion when using Atom on a second monitor.

Reproducible, but not consistently nor by hand. Noticed generally after two instances:

1) The Atom window is moved between screens.
2) Atom is restarted after installing a new plugin.

Issue is persistent on two Windows 7x64 machines with DisplayFusion installed.
